Project Description  The  Project  is  designed  to  improve  the  quality  of  life  of  residents  of 
small  towns  in  the  Lao  PDR  and  enhance  small  towns’  roles  as 
market,  services,  and  manufacturing  centers  supporting  the  rural 
hinterlands.  It  will  further  support  the  decentralization  of  the  water 
supply sector─ following the Government’s water supply sector policy─ 
by  strengthening  the  regulatory  framework  and  the  sector’s  planning 
capacity.  In  addition,  the  Project  will  assist  the  Government  in 
implementing the updated water supply sector investment plan through 
investments in water supply systems and associated urban facilities in 
about 12 small towns in the Northern and Central Regions. Formulated 
as a sector project, the Project requires the towns and their provincial 
authorities  to  demonstrate  their  commitment  to  the  Project  and  its 
associated  reforms.  It  has  a  strong  community  participation  focus 
reinforced  by  integrated  poverty  reduction,  and  health  and  hygiene 
promotion  programs.  New  approaches  to  small  town  water  supply 
models and strategies to curtail capital costs have been introduced. 
 
The Lao PDR has successfully reduced the nation’s poverty incidence 
from  45%  in  1993  to  32%  in  2003.  However,  due  to  unbalanced 
economic  development,  poverty  incidence  fell  only  marginally  in  the 
Northern  Region,  which  has  the  highest  incidence  of  poverty  at  52% 
and is home to 25 of the nation’s 47 poor districts officially identified as 
priorities  for  development.  The  Government’s  National  Growth  and 
Poverty  Eradication  Strategy  (NGPES,  2004)  aims  to  reduce  poverty 
through  strong  economic  growth  and  increased  emphasis  on  the 
poorest  districts.  It  focuses  on  health,  including  water  supply  and 
sanitation, as one of four priority sectors for poverty reduction. Having 
been  neglected  in  past  investments,  small  towns  with  populations 
ranging  from  2,000  to  20,000  remain  underdeveloped—overall  piped 
water supply service coverage is only about 17% compared with 69% 
in Vientiane and the four largest secondary towns. More than 50% of 
households do not have any form of water-sealed toilets and less than 
10% of primary schools have latrines. Roads have mainly gravel or dirt 
pavements,  with  low  coverage  of  roadside  drains.  Residents  in  small 
towns  spend  considerable  time,  energy,  and  financial  resources 
acquiring  their  daily  water  needs.  Low  coverage  of  safe  piped  water

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

2. 
The Lao PDR has one of the smallest populations (total of about 5.7 million in 2003) and 
lowest  population  densities  (25  persons/square  kilometer)  in  Southeast  Asia.  However,  its 
population growth rate of 2.5% is among the highest in the region, and the population is projected 
to  reach  8.2  million  by  2020.  About  80%  (4.5  million)  of  the  people  live  in  nearly  12,000  small 
rural  villages  scattered  throughout  the  country.  The  remaining  20%  (1.2  million)  are  urban 
residents who live in 145 officially designated urban centers in 142 districts. While the Lao PDR 
remains essentially a rural country, urban centers are playing an increasingly important role in the 
country’s economy, evidenced by (i) the quick growth in the industry sector in the past decade; 
and  (ii)  the  Government’s  socioeconomic  development  strategies  increasingly  emphasizing  the 
development of urban centers, particularly small towns.2   
 
A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

3. 
Socioeconomic and Poverty Indicators. Although it has had consistent improvement in 
most socioeconomic indicators over the past few years, the Lao PDR remains one of the world’s 
least-developed countries. It ranked 135th among 177 countries in the 2004 Human Development 
Report  of  the  United  Nations  Development  Programme  (UNDP).  The  country’s  gross  domestic 
product (GDP) grew at an average annual rate of 6.4% during 1993–2003. The GDP per capita in 
2003 was about $350. While agriculture still accounts for about half of the GDP, the industry has 
been growing fastest in the past decade at an average annual rate of about 10.5%, followed by 
services  at  6.7%,  and  agriculture  at  5.0%.  Government  revenue  was  about  11.0%  of  GDP  and 
expenditure about 18.8% of GDP in 2003. The budget deficit of about 7.8% of GDP was financed 
mostly  by  grants  and  external  concessional  loans.  External  debt  stood  at  around  $3.0  billion  or 
about 170% of GDP in 2003. Poverty incidence fell from about 45% in 1993 to 32% in 20033 due 
to strong economic growth. However, it fell only marginally in the Northern Region, which has the 
highest  incidence  of  poverty  at  52%,  because  of  unbalanced  economic  development.  The 
Northern  Region  has  25  of  the  nation’s  47  poor  districts  officially  identified  as  priorities  for 
development. The Central Region, with a poverty incidence of 35%, has 16 similar poor districts.4 
While poverty in the country is most evident in the rural areas, the urban poor are also severely 
affected  by  environmental  degradation,  unclean  water,  lack  of  proper  sanitation,  and  lack  of 
access to essential services.

5. 
Sector  Institutions.  Since  1995,  the  Government  has  introduced  a  series  of  reforms 
aiming  to  decentralize  responsibility  for  urban  and  rural  infrastructure  and  services  to  the 
increasing 
provincial  governments.  Accordingly,  each  provincial  government  has 
responsibility  for  urban  infrastructure  and  services,  which  are  managed  on  its  behalf  by  the 
provincial  Department  of  Communications,  Transport,  Posts,  and  Construction  (DCTPC)  and  its 
district  offices  (OCTPC).  In  1999,  Government  Decision  37/PM 7   on  Management  and 
Development of the Water Supply and Wastewater Sector (the Policy Statement) established an 
institutional  framework  and  long-term  vision  for  the  sector.  The  main  operational  impacts  of 
Decision 37/PM were to devolve responsibility for urban water supply and sanitation (WSS) from 
the  central  to  the  provincial  government,  and  to  create  a  new  organization,  the  Water  Supply 
Authority  (WASA),  under  the  Ministry  of  Communication,  Transport,  Posts  and  Construction 
(MCTPC).  The  Nam  Papa  Lao  (NPL  or  Lao  Water  Supply  Company),  which  was  previously 
responsible  for  water  supply  for  the  whole  country,  was  then  broken  into  Nam  Papa  Vientiane 
(NPV or Vientiane Water Supply Company, in charge of water supply in Vientiane) and provincial 
nam  papas  (PNPs,  provincial  water  supply  companies  looking  after  the  water  supply  service  in 
each province). From late 1999, each PNP became an autonomous state-owned enterprise under 
DCTPC. While WASA  was established to assist the MCTPC  minister on technical issues in the 
water  supply  sector  and  to  manage/monitor  the  implementation  of  water  supply  sector  policies, 
the  Government’s  long-term  vision  is  to  gradually  develop  WASA  as  an  effective  and  capable 
sector  regulator.  Decision  37/PM  also  provided  for  the  formation  of  a  regulatory  committee  to 
oversee  and  direct  WASA’s  operations,  and  the  committee  is  now  being  established.  A  water 
supply sector analysis is summarized in Appendix 1.

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

10. 
Although the Government has introduced a number of policies and reforms since 1999 to 
improve  the  sustainability  of  the  WSS  sector,  such  changes  have  not  been  translated  into 
practice in a coherent way. The key problems that need to be addressed in the short to medium 
term are as follows:  
 
Unbalanced and Inadequate Investment. Despite considerable investments in the urban 
11. 
water  sector  in  the  past,  overall  piped  water  supply  coverage  in  small  towns  (at  17%)  is  well 
below targeted levels. Further investment in water supply and associated urban infrastructure in 
the  remaining  97  underserved  small  towns  is  urgently  needed  to  address  unsatisfactory  health 
profiles  and  deteriorating  environmental  conditions.  The  proposed  Project  will  provide  safe, 
reliable  piped  water  supply  and  complementary  small-scale  improvements  in  drainage  and 
sanitation and, in some cases, roads and bridges for about 12 priority small towns in the SIP. The 
design and monitoring framework is Appendix 3. 
 
12. 
High Capital Investment Costs. Initial per capita investment costs in water supply in the 
Lao  PDR  have  been  5–10  times  greater  than  in  neighboring  countries  because  of  (i)  low 
population density; (ii) high cost of construction in remote areas; (iii) inappropriate service levels; 
(iv)  need  to  import  most  equipment  and  materials;  and  (v)  Government’s  high  and  opaque 
subsidies, which have acted as disincentives to adopting least cost solutions for the water supply 
systems.  High  investment  cost  has  become  a  constraint  in  achieving  the  Government’s  sector 
development  goal.  Strategies  for  cost  containment,  such  as  appropriate  technology  and  design 
criteria, tariff reforms, and proper cost recovery levels are  needed to encourage PNPs to adopt 
least-cost solutions for their water supply systems. 
 
13. 
Unsustainable Tariffs.  Following decentralization, PNPs were expected to be financially 
self-supporting,  and  responsibility  for  tariff  setting  was  delegated  to  the  respective  provincial 
governments.  In  practice,  tariffs  set  on  a  province-wide  basis  are  insufficient  to  cover  operation 
and  maintenance  (O&M)  costs,  let  alone  debt  service  or  depreciation.  As  a  result,  most  PNPs 
operate  at  a  loss  and  require  subsidies  from  provincial  governments.  In  most  provinces,  debt 
recovery  has  proven  to  be  difficult.  While  the  water  bill  collection  efficiency  from  households  is 
generally  good,  many  government  agencies  fail  to  pay  their  water  bills.  The  province-wide  tariff 
structure, together with government relending arrangements to provinces (currently only 15% of 
capital cost is passed on as loan), has acted as disincentives to adopting least-cost solutions to 
the water supply systems. These factors combine to result in unsustainable, deteriorating water 
supply systems and ultimately lead to poor customer service. To overcome these impediments to 
financial sustainability, the Government has issued a National Water Supply Tariff Policy. WASA 
is  now  assisting  PNPs  to  establish  tariffs  at  levels  sufficient  for  sustainable  operation,  and  to 
adopt appropriate water supply service levels. Under the proposed Project, the Government has 
agreed to adopt the following tariff reforms for each subproject town: (i) subproject-specific tariffs; 
(ii) a progressive tariff structure with three consumption blocks (lifeline, average, above average); 
and  (iii)  tariffs  in  each  town  to  be  set  at  levels designed  to  recover  full  O&M  costs  plus  30%  of 
capital investment costs. 
 
14.  Weak Regulatory Capacity. With assistance from ADB and NORAD, WASA has gone a 
long  way  since  its  establishment  in  1999  as  the  proposed  sector  regulator.  It  has  already 

  

5

prepared a number of key financial, technical, and accounting guidelines; facilitated private sector 
water supply initiatives; and published annual reports, which evaluated the technical and financial 
performance of all PNPs in the country. However, WASA’s regulatory capacity remains weak due 
mainly to (i) lack of a solid legal foundation for sector regulation, (ii) limited and unstable human 
resources,  and  (iii)  unclear  division  of  responsibilities  in  relation  to  the  Department  of  Housing 
and  Urban  Planning  (DHUP)/MCTPC,  which  assigns  many  policy  making,  sector  planning,  and 
project  implementation  responsibilities  to  WASA,  diverting  it  from  its  regulating  focus  and 
conflicting  with  its  regulating  functions.  The  Government  has  begun  the  steps  necessary  to 
establish  WASA  as  a  dedicated  regulatory  authority.  A  Prime  Minister  Decree  ─  Regulation  of 
Urban  Water  Supply  Operations─  which  sets  the  legal  foundation  and  clearly  specifies  the 
responsibilities,  staffing,  and  funding  arrangements  of  WASA  ─  is  expected  to  be  approved  in 
2005. Following approval of the decree, the Project will support WASA in recruiting and training 
qualified staff, developing its work program and assisting its implementation, and identifying the 
regular  internal  funding  resource  for  its  operations,  with  a  view  to  transforming  WASA  into  an 
effective and capable sector regulator in the future. 
 
15.  Weak  Institutional  Capacity  for  Sector  Planning  and  Policy  Development.  Under 
Decision  37/PM,  DHUP  is  responsible,  through  WSD,  for  setting  sector  development  strategies 
and  plans,  planning  staff  training,  and  studying  technical  standards  of  water  supply  systems. 
WSD is also tasked with managing an ambitious long-term program of capital investment in the 
urban water supply sector. To date, it has received little external assistance, except in the area of 
project management. As a result, WSD has limited capacity to undertake its core functions, with 
few  staff  and  resources.  In  addition,  overlapping  responsibilities  with  those  of  WASA  cause 
confusion.  These  limitations  pose  a  major  constraint  to  the  long-term  sustainability  of  the  water 
sector. To address these issues, the Project will support redefining DHUP’s responsibilities and 
will provide institutional strengthening to assist WSD in recruiting and training staff, and preparing 
various key policy and strategy documents as well as technical and management guidelines.  
 
16. 
Inadequate  Sanitation  Coverage,  Low  Sanitation  Awareness,  Weak  Sanitation 
Regulations and Poor Management of On-Site Sanitation. In small towns, only about 42% of 
households have pour-flush toilets; communities have low awareness of the links between water, 
sanitation,  hygiene,  and  health;  and  provincial  sanitation  regulations  are  weak,  with  poorly 
defined  institutional  responsibilities.  The  Project  will  address  these  issues  by  (i)  increasing  the 
coverage of public and poor household sanitation systems by providing funds for construction of 
new  sanitation  facilities;  (ii)  improving  the  drainage  networks;  (iii)  implementing  the  community 
health  and  sanitation  awareness  program  in  the  project  towns;  (iv)  requiring  provincial 
governments  to  introduce  modified  sanitation  regulations  with  clearly  defined  institutional 
responsibilities  (to  be  submitted  with  the  subproject  appraisal  report)  as  a  precondition  to 
receiving ADB funding for the subproject; and (v) strengthening the capacity of local agencies and 
households  to  manage,  operate,  and  maintain  on-site  sanitation  facilities,  by  providing  training 
and  O&M  equipment.  All  households,  businesses  and  institutions  will  be  required  to  have 
OCTPC-approved  sanitation  systems  before  they  are  permitted  to  connect  to  the  PNP  piped 
water supply system.  
 
17. 
Lessons Learned. The project design draws on the experience and lessons learned from 
previous ADB and other agencies’ projects in the Lao PDR, particularly the ongoing WSSSP, the 
Small  Towns  Development  Project,  and  the  Northern  Provincial  Towns  Water  Supply  and

capital  costs;  (iii)  adequate  time  and  resources  should  be  devoted  to  raw  water  assessment 
(especially  spring  sources  and  groundwater)  to  minimize  water  treatment  costs  and  the  risk  of

recovery  levels  will  provide  greater  incentive  for  PNPs  to  adopt  least-cost  solutions  and  for 
consumers to save water.  
 
32. 
Assessment  of  Raw  Water  Source.  Stream flow records in the Lao PDR are available 
for  the  major  rivers  only,  and  generally,  no  data  is  available  for  local  streams  and  springs  that 
could be the least-cost sources for many small towns. Yield assessments of surface sources for 
previous  projects  have  often  relied  on  local  knowledge  of  district  agencies  and  spot 
measurements of stream flow at the time of field inspections. This has often resulted in a high risk 
of  water  shortages  after  scheme  commissioning  or,  alternatively  has  required  designers  to 
choose  more  conservative  and  expensive  schemes  on  larger  streams  with  assured  flows.  To 
minimize  the  risk  of  water  shortages  and  ensure  the  development  of  least-cost  sources, 
resources  have  been  allocated  from  the  Project  Preparatory  TA  for  continued  flow  and  water 
quality measurements during the 2005 dry and wet seasons for the five candidate subprojects to 
be  implemented  under  phase  1  (para.  39).  In  addition,  the  Government  has  agreed  to  make 
PNPs  throughout  the  country  undertake  regular  dry-  and  wet-season  flow  and  quality 
measurements for potential sources of small town water supply systems, and relevant training will 
be  provided  under  the  Project.  The  participation  of  PNPs  in  this  exercise  will  be  taken  into 
account in future subproject selection criteria for ADB-financed water supply projects.

increased use of domestic sanitation facilities due to increased awareness, appropriate sanitation

directly or indirectly. Of about 187,000 project beneficiaries in 2010, about 40% or 76,000 will be 
the  poor.  Socially  inclusive  processes  incorporated  in  the  Project  will  ensure  that  the  poor  will

the  needs  of  the  poor  in  particular.  Under  this  subcomponent,  the  poorest  villages  will  have 
priority for basic infrastructure and services improvement. To ensure responsiveness to the needs 
of the poor, the VEI assigns greater active roles to the village residents, particularly the poor, in

will experience greater benefits in terms of timesavings, reduced drudgery, and improved family

A. 

Country Background  

1. 
The Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) is essentially a rural country, with a 
total  population  of  around  5.7  million.  About  4.5  million  or  80%  live  a  largely  subsistence 
existence  in  nearly  12,000  small  rural  villages  scattered  throughout  the  country.  Although  the 
economy  is  still  largely  rural,  with  agriculture  accounting  for  some  50%  of  gross  domestic 
product  (GDP),  the  role  of  the  urban  sector  is  growing.  During  1997–2003  the  industry  and 
services  sector  components  of  the  GDP  increased  at  average  annual  rates  of  around  10%, 
compared  with  around  5%  for  agriculture,  reflecting  increased  activity  and  productivity  and 
greater  opportunities  in  urban  areas.  The  urban  sector  encompasses  145  officially  designated 
urban centers or towns in 142 districts. These towns have a combined population of 1.2 million, 
or  about  20%  of  the  country’s  total  population.  The  five  largest  towns  include  the  capital, 
Vientiane (population about 300,000), and four secondary towns (populations 20,000–60,000), 
accounting  for  45%  of  the  total  urban  population.  The  provincial  and  district  towns,  with 
populations ranging from 5,000 to 20,000, are classified as small towns. Development of these 
small towns is an important part of the Government’s national development agenda, which aims 
to achieve the overall goal of exiting least-developed-country status by 2020 through sustained 
equitable economic growth and social development. The small towns function as administrative 
and economic centers for their surrounding rural areas, and act as economic links between the 
rural areas and national and international markets. They are the locations of immediate markets, 
transport depots, and agricultural processing centers in the rural hinterland.  
 
B. 

Quality and Coverage of Urban Water Supply and Sanitation 

2. 
Over the past decade, all 16 provinces, the capital Vientiane, and the special economic 
zone  have  benefited  from  substantial  investments  in  water  supply  systems,  primarily  through 
assistance from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and other external agencies. While about 
69%  of  the  urban  population  in  Vientiane  and  the  four  secondary  towns  have  piped  water 
supply, overall coverage in urban areas is only 39% (2003). Water supply coverage in the 140 
small towns is only about 17%, and most residents rely on shallow wells, ponds and streams, 
which  are  often  biologically  contaminated.  Women  and  children  spend  as  much  as  1–2  hours 
each  day  fetching  water  from  distant  sources.  Table  A1  summarizes  the  status  of  PNP-piped 
water supply systems in urban centers throughout the country. 
 
3. 
None  of  the  urban  centers  has  a  functioning  municipal  wastewater  treatment  system. 
Individual property owners are responsible for developing and managing their on-site sanitation 
systems.  Overall,  about  54%  of  urban  households  have  pour-flush  toilets,  but  there  are  large 
differences  in  coverage  between  the  five  largest  towns  (78%  coverage)  and  the  small  towns 
(42% coverage). Some 46% of urban residents do not have proper toilet facilities and use open 
ground, fields, local drains, and watercourses for disposal of excreta and wastewater. There are 
few  public  toilets  in  markets  and  temples,  and  less  than  10%  of  primary  schools  have  proper 
latrines.  Pour-flush  toilets  with  pit  latrines  generally  provide  a  satisfactory  form  of  wastewater 
disposal  in  low-density  areas  because  of  the  natural  assimilative  capacity  of  the  subsoil. 
However,  problems  often  arise  because  of  poor  design  or  construction,  unsuitable  soil  or 
groundwater conditions, lack of maintenance, and low hygiene and sanitation awareness. About 
7% of households use septic tanks systems discharging to drains or soakaways. Septic systems 
required  in  medium  and  high-density  areas  but  often  provide  only  partial  treatment  of 
wastewater,  because  they  are  not  constructed  to  proper  standards  and  are  not  emptied 
regularly. Due to poor functioning of the drainage network, partially treated septic tank effluent 
or seepage is often detained in the populated areas, posing risks to the public and polluting the

Sector Policy, Decentralization, and Sector Institutions 

4. 
In  the  early  to  late  1990s,  management  of  all  the  nation’s urban  water  supply  systems

(MCTPC).  Provincial  water  supply  offices  reported  directly  to  NPL  and  system  revenues  were 
consolidated under one central account. Subsidies from the large Vientiane scheme to the then 
20 or so smaller provincial urban systems masked the poor performance of the sector generally 
and  the  smaller  schemes  in  particular.  In  1996  the  Law  on  Water  and  Water  Resources  was 
signed  under  Presidential  Decree  No.  126/PR.  The  law  established  the  broad  principles, 
regulations, and measures for the managing, exploiting, using, and developing water and water 
resources in the Lao PDR.  
 
5. 
Subsequently,  in  1999,  in  Prime  Ministerial  Decision  No.  37/PM,  the  policy  on 
management  and  development  of  the  water  supply  sector,  or  the  Sector  Policy  Statement 
(SPS), was enacted. It sets the water supply sector goal as to provide 24 hours daily access to 
safe drinking water for 80% of the urban population by the year 2020. According to the policy, 
MCTPC  has  overall  responsibility  for  managing  the  urban  water  supply  sector,  while  The 
National  Center  for  Environmental  Health  (Nam  Sa’at)  is  responsible  for  managing  the  rural 
water  supply  sector  under  the  Ministry  of  Health.  The  main  operational  impacts  of  Decision 
37/PM were to create a new organization, the Water Supply Authority (WASA) under MCTPC, 
and  to  devolve  responsibility  for  urban  water  supply  and  sanitation  from  central  to  provincial 
governments. From late 1999, each provincial water supply enterprise (known as nam papa or 
provincial  nam  papa  [PNP])  became  an  autonomous  SOE  operating  under  the  supervision  of 
the  provincial  Department  of  Communication,  Transport,  Post  and  Communication  (DCTPC). 
The  provincial  government  owns  the  urban  water  supply  system,  while  the  PNPs  are 
responsible  for  managing  the  systems.  Nam  Papa  Vientiane,  operator  of  the  capital’s  water 
supply systems became a separate agency under DCTPC of Vientiane prefecture but retained 
the important role of training the new PNPs.

Sector  reorganization  arising  from  37/PM  had  its  largest  impact  on  the  PNPs,  which 
6. 
were  transformed  from  branch  offices  of  NPL  to  individual  state  owned  enterprises  (SOEs). 
They  were  suddenly  cut  off  from  the  financial  subsidies  and  much  of  the  technical, 
administrative, and managerial assistance formerly provided by NPL. Accordingly, ADB, World 
Bank,  Agence  Française  de  Développement  (AFD),  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency 
(JICA),  and  other  agencies  have  provided  PNPs  with  capacity  building  programs  since  1999, 
most of which are still ongoing. Following decentralization, PNPs were intended to be financially 
self-supporting,  and  responsibility  for  tariff  setting  was  given  to  the  respective  provincial 
governments.  In  practice,  tariffs  set  on  a  province-wide  basis  are  insufficient  to  cover  proper 
operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  costs,  let  alone  debt  service  or  depreciation.  As  a  result, 
most  PNPs  operate  at  a  loss  and  require  subsidies  from  provincial  governments.  In  most 
provinces,  government  agencies  are  delinquent  in  paying  their  water  bills.  Government 
onlending arrangements to provinces (currently only 15% of capital cost is passed on as loan) 
have  acted  as  a  disincentive  to  adopting  least  cost  solutions  to  their  water  supply  systems. 
These  factors  combine  to  result  in  unsustainable,  deteriorating  water  supply  systems  and 
ultimately to poor customer service. To overcome these impediments to financial sustainability, 
the  Government,  with  WASA  assistance,  issued  a  National  Water  Supply  Tariff  Policy  in  April 
2004. WASA now assists PNPs to establish tariffs at levels sufficient for sustainable operation 
and to adopt appropriate water supply service levels. 
 
Under  Decision  37/PM,  the  Department  of  Housing  and  Urban  Planning  (DHUP)  is 
7. 
responsible, through its Water Supply Division (WSD), for setting sector development strategies 
and  plans,  planning  staff  training,  and  studying  technical  standards  of  water  supply  systems. 
WSD also has the task of managing an ambitious long-term program of capital investment in the 
urban water supply and sanitation sector, but to date it has  received little external assistance, 
except  in  the  area  of  project  management.  As  a  result,  WSD  has  very  limited  capacity  to 
undertake its core functions, and it has few staff and resources. In addition, its responsibilities 
overlap with those of WASA, causing confusion. These limitations pose a major constraint to the 
long-term sustainability of the water sector.  
 
8. 
Following  Decision  37/PM,  WASA  was  established  in  1999  to  assist  the  Minister  of 
MCTPC  to  plan,  manage  and  regulate  the  water  supply  sector.  Its  assigned  functions  include 
strategic planning, formulating regulations, establishing technical standards and specifications, 
and  managing  and  monitoring  the  water  sector.  The  Government’s  long-term  vision  is  to 
gradually  develop  WASA  as  an  effective  and  capable  sector  regulator.  Immediately  after  its 
establishment, WASA took over NPL’s role of managing externally funded projects. The project 
management activities not only diverted WASA’s focus from its core regulatory and monitoring 
functions,  but  also  conflicted  with  its  intended  role  as  regulator.  Since  2001,  DHUP’s  project 
management  capacity  has  been  strengthened  and  it  has  gradually  assumed  the  project 
management  function  from  WASA.  In  2003  and  2004,  WASA  focused  increasingly on  its  core 
regulatory  functions,  which  included:  (i)  coordinating  and  collating  financial  and  performance 
information from PNPs; (ii) publishing the annual water sector performance reports for 2002 and 
2003,  which  evaluated  the  technical  and  financial  performance  of  all  PNPs  throughout  the 
country; (iii) preparing tariff guidelines, and assisting with preparation of the water tariff policy; 
(iv) preparing water quality guidelines; and (v) preparing accounting and reporting guidelines for 
PNPs.  It  also  carried  out  technical  activities  assigned  by  DHUP,  including  updating  the  sector 
investment  plan  for  urban  water  supply  and  facilitating  private  sector  participation  proposals. 
However, the regulation capacity of WASA remains weak due mainly to (i) lack of a solid legal 
foundation, (ii) limited and unstable human resources, and (iii) unclear division of responsibilities 
in relation to DHUP/MCTPC. The Government has begun the steps necessary to install WASA 
as a dedicated regulatory authority and a Prime Minister Decree on Regulation of Urban Water

promoting,  and  managing  urban  environmental  hygiene;  (ii)  each  provincial  government  is

D. 

Sector Funding and Investment Plans 

10. 
Capital investments in the urban water supply sector are funded almost entirely through 
external  assistance,  while  tariffs  and  other  user  charges  applied  by  the  PNPs  fund  O&M. 
Between  2001  and  2004,  allocations  made  through  the  Government  for  capital  investments  in 
the  urban  and  water  supply  sector  totaled  $39.6  million,  an  average  of  about  $9.9  million 
annually. Virtually all of this funding was provided through external assistance in a mix of grants 
and  loans,  while  a  very  small  amount  came  from  the  Government’s  own  internal  resources.  
Currently  only  15%  capital  costs  of  the  water  supply  systems  are  passed  on  as  loan  to  the 
PNPs. Repayment of these onlent amounts, as well as O&M costs, are funded from the PNPs’ 
operating revenues. However, the revenues have been insufficient to achieve adequate levels 
of  O&M.  In  2002  and  2003,  the  PNPs  generated  total operating  revenues  of $3.6 million  from 
water tariffs and $4.1 million from other user charges. However, because the timely collection of 
billed  revenue  is  a  significant  problem  for  almost  all  PNPs,  actual  cash  flows  into  the  sector 
generated from those sources are lower. 
 
11. 
To  meet  the  sector  goal,  the  Government  prepared  in  1999  a  sector  investment  plan 
(SIP)  that  listed  all  urban  center  water  supply  systems  in  order  of  priority  for  rehabilitation, 
expansion,  or  development.  The  SIP  has  guided  sector  development  in  the  past  5  years, 
including  investments  funded  by  ADB  and  other  external  agencies.  The  SIP  was  updated 
recently  under  TA  4377-LAO1  to  reflect  the  Government’s  increasing  emphasis  on  equitable 
development  by  improving  the  small  towns,  particularly  those  in  the  poorest  districts.  The 
updated  SIP  (Appendix  2),  which  estimates  future  investment  needs  of  about  $267  million, 
including  $103  million  for  small  towns,  represents  a  balanced,  stepwise  approach  to  water 
supply  development  in  the  country.  It  is  considered  realistic  and  achievable  based  on 
experience and the Government’s performance in implementing projects over the past decade. 
The  investments  under  the  updated  SIP  are  prioritized  according  to  factors,  including 
population; poverty status; location relative to a major road, transport node, growth corridor, or 
international border; tourism potential; and provincial government’s development priority. Out of 
the 18 small towns having first priority in the updated SIP, 12 are in the northern region and 6 
are in the central regions.

Alignment with the Country’s Development and Poverty Reduction Strategies. The 
Government’s National Growth and Poverty Eradication Strategy (NGPES, 2004), which aims to

The Government’s water supply sector goal is to provide 24-hour daily access to safe drinking 
water for 80% of the urban population by the year 2020. The Project will assist the Government

clean water jeopardizes both the physical and social health of people. It is an affront to human 
dignity. The Project targets reduction of human poverty by improving access to clean water by 
the urban poor, particularly vulnerable groups consisting of women and children. The Project will 
assist  the  Government  in  its  efforts  to  achieve  MDGs  4,  6,  and  7—reducing  child  mortality, 
combating malaria and other diseases, and halving the proportion of people without sustainable 
access to safe drinking water—and will contribute directly to the millennium development targets

B. Poverty Analysis  
The  Lao  PDR  has  a  total  population  of  about  5.7  million  with  a  population  density  of  about  25  persons/km2. 
Compared  with  its  neighboring  countries,  the  Lao  PDR  has  one  of  the  highest  population  growth  rates  at  2.5% 
per  year.  By  2020,  the  population  is  projected  to  reach  8.2  million  people.  About  80%  of  the  population  live  in 
nearly 12,000 small rural villages scattered throughout the country and 20% are urban residents in 145 officially 
designated urban centers in 142 districts. While the Lao PDR remains essentially a rural country, urban centers 
are playing an increasing role in its economy. The country’s gross domestic product (GDP) grew at an average 
annual  rate  of  6.4%  during  1993-2002.  The  GDP  per  capita  in  2003  was  about  $330.  The  industry  sector 
experienced the highest growth of about 10.5% per year. The growth rate of the urban population has increased 
nearly twice as fast as the national average. 
 
There has been consistent improvement in most socioeconomic indicators over the past few years. The country has 
experienced a sharp reduction in poverty incidence in the past 10 years: from 45% in 1992/93, to 32% in 2002/03. 
This reduction has been associated with strong economic growth, achievement of rice self-sufficiency and increased 
cross-border trade. However, the Lao PDR remains the least developed, as it ranks as 135 among 177 countries in 
the  United  Nations  Development  Programme  2004  Human  Development  Report.  Economic  development  remains 
imbalanced  throughout  Lao  PDR,  with  marginal  improvements  witnessed  in  the  Northern  Region.  The  Northern 
Region has the highest incidence of poverty and faces the greatest challenges due to (i) environmental degradation; 
(ii)  poor  physical  and  social  infrastructure;  (iii)  geographical  remoteness;  and  (iv)  limited  access  to  markets, 
information, economic growth opportunities, and quality social services.  
 
Water  supply  and  environmental  improvements  are  important  in  controlling  disease  outbreaks  and  epidemics 
associated  with  safe  and  clean  water  supply  and  proper  sanitation  and  hygiene.  Overall  coverage  of  piped  water 
supply  in  small  towns  is  about  17%  compared  with  69%  in  Vientiane  and  the  four  largest  secondary  towns.  More 
than 50% of households in small towns do not have any form of water-sealed toilets and less than 10% of primary 
schools  have  latrines.  Limited  access  of  the  poor  to  roads  in  the  wet  season  hinders  their  access  to  schools, 
markets, and health facilities.  
 
The Project will benefit about 89,000 small town residents by 2010 and about 100,000 by 2015 in about 12 towns. 
By  2010,  an  additional  98,000  rural  residents  in  surrounding  areas  will  indirectly  benefit  from  improved  access  to 
urban  markets  and  government  services.  About  76,000  beneficiaries  (or  40%)  are  estimated  to  be  poor  in  2010. 
Project  components  include  (i)  institutional  capacity  building  for  Water  Supply  Authority  (WASA)  and  the  Water 
Sector  Division  of  Department  of  Housing  and  Urban  Planning,  Ministry  of  Communication,  Transport,  Posts  and 
Construction  (DHUP/MCTPC);  (ii)  development  of  a  water  supply  system;  (iii)  road,  drain,  and  sanitation 
improvements;  (iv)  participation,  awareness,  and  community  actions  (PACA);  and  (v)  project  implementation 
assistance to different levels of the government, including District Offices of Communication, Transport, Posts and 
Construction  (OCTPCs)  and the  district  branches  of  the  provincial  nam  papas  (PNPs). The  PACA  component  will 
support  ongoing  efforts  about  hygiene  and  proper  lifestyle,  and  will  coordinate  with  ongoing  health  information, 
education, and communication (IEC) campaigns.

D.  Gender Development 

Lao  women  play  important  roles  in  agriculture  and  other  economic  activities,  and  are  responsible  for  a  variety  of

water-related  diseases  and  reproductive  health  problems).  Upgrading  roads  will  improve  women’s  access  to 
markets, extension and social services, and information. Public toilet facilities at schools will provide more privacy 
for girls attending school, and will positively influence enrollment rates. At present, less than 10% of primary schools 
have latrines. Institutionally, women are active in the Water Supply Division of DHUP/MCTPC, Lao Women’s Union, 
and in OCTPCs and PNPs at the district levels. A gender strategy has been prepared for the Project (Appendix 12).

nearly 12,000 small rural villages scattered throughout the country and 20% are urban residents in 145 officially

annual  rate  of  6.4%  during  1993-2002.  The  GDP  per  capita  in  2003  was  about  $330.  The  industry  sector

nearly twice as fast as the national average. 
 
There has been consistent improvement in most socioeconomic indicators over the past few years. The country has 
experienced a sharp reduction in poverty incidence in the past 10 years: from 45% in 1992/93, to 32% in 2002/03.

kip  (KN).  All  costs  were  derived  from  the  financial  project  costs  and  reexpressed  in  economic 
prices using the domestic price numeraire. Taxes and duties were deducted as appropriate from 
base costs. Tradable components were adjusted to economic prices using a shadow exchange 
rate  factor  (SERF),1  while  nontraded  components  were  valued  at  domestic  market  prices.  A 
shadow wage rate factor (SWRF) for unskilled labor was applied to reflect its opportunity cost in 
the context of wide availability of labor in the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR).2  
 
B. 

Demand Forecast 

3. 
Water demand in the sample subproject towns was derived from the current populations 
within  the  planned  service  areas,  population  growth,  current  and  future  domestic  water 
consumption  levels,  and  a  provision  for  nondomestic  water  consumption.  Reliable  data  on  the 
amount  of  water  presently  consumed  by  households  in  the  subproject  towns  is  not  available. 
Households  typically  utilize  a  variety  of  water  sources  and  do  not  measure  or  assess  their 
consumption. However, based on previous surveys and studies, as well as observations of water 
use  behavior  in  the  subproject  towns,  it  is  estimated  that  average  daily  demand  from  existing 
sources  ranges  between  40  and  70  liter  per  capita  per  day  (lpcd)  depending  on  the  effort  and 
resources  needed  to  acquire  the  water,  and  on  income  levels.  The  lifeline  consumption 
requirement was estimated to be 40 lpcd. Per capita water consumption is expected to increase 
after  construction  of  the  piped  water  supply  system,  due  primarily  to  (i)  the  reduced  cost  of 
acquiring  water,  (ii)  improved  water  quality,  and  (iii)  greater  convenience  and  reliability  of  the 
piped water supply system. However, demand is also a function of price and household income 
and accurate estimates of the impact of these factors require analysis of extensive historical data, 
which  are  not  available  for  the  Lao  PDR.  Therefore,  while  the  demand  forecasts  incorporate 
estimated  price  and  income  elasticity,  the  reliability  of  these  estimates  is  limited  by  the  lack  of 
detailed  historic  data.  Previous  experience  in  the  sector  indicates  that  the  per  capita  water 
consumption levels tend to be overestimated. For example, the original design criteria employed 
for the ongoing Water Supply and Sanitation Sector Project (WSSP) was based on consumption 
of 120 lpcd. However, on the basis of actual consumption patterns, that figure was reduced to 100 
lpcd for WSSP phase IIb subprojects. Considering the higher tariffs to be adopted and alternative 
water  resources  available  for  noncritical  water  usage  by  some  households,  postproject  water 
consumption in the three sample subproject towns was estimated to be 85 lpcd. 
 
C.

4. 
Least-cost  analysis  was  undertaken  to  evaluate  different  technical  options,  including 
alternative  water  sources,  the  size  and  timing  of  water  treatment  plants,  reservoirs,  and

D. 

Economic Benefits 

5. 
The  economic  benefits  of  the  subproject  water  supply  and  sanitation  components 
include  cost  savings  associated  with  the  replacement  of  nonincremental  water  supplies  with 
those  from  the  new  piped  water  supply  system,  benefits  from  incremental  water  consumption 
provided  by  these  new  systems,  and  improved  public  health.  Presently,  residents  in  the 
subproject towns use a variety of water sources, including rivers, wells, rainwater, bottled water, 
and  private  vendors.  Costs  associated  with  these  existing  supplies  include  source/treatment 
costs, collection costs, storage costs, and financial expenditures made in purchasing water. The 
savings generated from the Project are the avoided costs associated with these supply sources. 
This  is  calculated  as  existing  water  consumption  multiplied  by  the  weighted  average  cost  of 
water from these existing sources, which is estimated at KN25,300/cubic meter (m3) for Houn, 
KN20,900/m3 for Kenethao, and KN18,500/m3 for Nan. While health benefits are also expected 
from the improved water supply and sanitation services, they were not included in the benefit-
cost analysis due to lack of reliable data and because these benefits were partially captured in 
the households’ willingness to pay. 
 
E. 

Results of Economic Analysis 

6. 
The  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  for  the  sample  subprojects  was  calculated 
as 22.3% for Houn, 19.1% for Kenethao, and 22.7% for Nan, well above the 12% EOCC (Table 
A15). On this basis, all three subprojects are considered economically viable. An analysis was 
undertaken  to  test  the  sensitivity  of  the  EIRR  to  adverse  changes  in  selected  variables.  The 
variables tested were (i) 10% increase in subproject capital costs; (i) 10% increase in subproject 
O&M costs; (iii) 10% reduction in subproject benefits; (iv) 1-year delay in completing subproject 
construction, which delays subproject benefits by 1 year and results in 10% increase in capital 
costs incurred over the final 2 years of construction; and (v) a combination of the four previous 
variables. Of the single variable scenarios, the EIRR is most sensitive to the 1-year delay, but 
remains well above the EOCC. Even under the worst case scenario, in which all four adverse 
variables  are  combined,  each  of  the  subprojects  remains  economically  viable  with  EIRRs  of 
16.4% for Houn, 13.8% for Kenethao, and 16.6% for Nan.

4. 
Financial  Objectives.  Each  PNP  participating  in  the  Project  will  implement  subproject 
specific tariffs that are sufficient to (i) fully recover operation and maintenance (O&M) costs, (ii) 
recover  all  subproject  debt  service,  (iii)  maintain  a  debt  service  ratio  of  at  least  1.2  once  the 
subproject  is  fully  operational,  and  (iv)  gradually  recover  an  increasing  proportion  of  annual 
depreciation expense on the subproject fixed assets. Furthermore, each participating PNP will 
achieve an overall debt service ratio of at least 1.2 and maintain its accounts receivable at less 
than 90 days of annual sales, the same as that required under the ongoing Water Supply and 
Sanitation Sector Project (WSSSP). Under the Project, however, 30% of the subproject cost will 
be re-lent to the PNPs, compared with 15% for the WSSSP. 
 
5. 
Operating  Revenues. Operating revenues were derived from water sales, meter rental 
charges, connection fees, and miscellaneous income. Future water sales were calculated on the 
basis  of  water  demand  (Appendix  15)  and  projected  water  tariff  levels.  For  the  subprojects, 
tariffs are set to meet the agreed upon financial objectives for the subprojects. Tariffs were set 
in accordance with those recommended by the Water Supply Authority (WASA) for 2005–2007.1 
Tariffs beyond 2007 were conservatively assumed to be increased annually at the local inflation 
rate.  Meter rental  income was estimated at an average of KN3,300 per month per meter for all 
customers,  expressed  in  2005  prices,  and  then  adjusted  each  year  by  the  local  inflation  rate. 
Connection  fees  were  set  at  the  estimated  average  cost  of  connection  plus  15%  overhead. 
Miscellaneous  revenue  derived  primarily  from  late  payment  penalties  was  estimated  at  3%  of 
water sales revenues. 
 
6. 
Operating Expenses. Annual O&M costs were projected separately for each subproject 
and  for  the  PNPs’  other  operations  over  the  entire  forecast  period  by  major  expense  item 
(personnel,  electricity,  chemicals,  maintenance,  administration,  new  connection  costs).  In 
addition,  the  projections  incorporated  the  turnover  tax  of  5%  of  water  sales  and  10%  of  other 
sales including connection costs. Depreciation expense was calculated on an average asset life 
of 25 years on a straight-line basis. Income tax was then applied at the rate of 35% on pre-tax 
income, or 1% of PNP revenue if there was no pre-tax income.
